app.note: On the shape of ṅa, see ṅabalay in l. 7.

HD didn't note on how the first word could be interpreted as diya. In fact this is a common manner of interpreting spelling Cya in Sundanese mss., HD sugest to emending the second word to diṅaran. HD already suggested that one needs to ḍiṅaran; we add that ḍyi needs to be read as dyə, the word we also find further on in this line and in line 4.

This reading seems impossible to us, for there is unmistakably a sign between the n and the following ḍi, and this sign can only be paten or punctuation. Since the word pran does not seem to exist in Sundanese nor Javanese, we propose to emend this to pun·, as in line 4
it would be possible to read dyəṁ ḍiṅaran

All predecessor have by their non-insertion of a space between ñusuk and na implied that na is a pronominal clitic, but it seems more convincing to take it as article na (s.v. na 5. For its use before topnyms, cf. BM vs. 60, 750; see Noorduyn & Teeuw on the issue of how to interpret na in Sundanese mss.
We do not see the anusvāra/cecak. On the issue of Cyi/Ciya see the note on line 2.
HD explains that the anusvāra/cecak is present although hard to read. We are inclined to assume that it is absent. Cf. the cases of sa ratu and rahyi for saṁ ratu and rahyiṁ (= rahiyaṁ) above.
We found a typical ka with stroke underline that represented paten.
There can be no doubt about this reading. See the toponym Gunuṅ Tiga in the Carita Parahyaṅan as cited by Pleyte (176).

HD reads Icu and proposes to emend as iñcu. Adding vocalisation -i to aksara A is the standard way to write Ə in Sundanese mss. E.g. PNRI L623 f. 30v4 shows precisely the same spelling, so there is no need to emend. See also Noorduyn & Teeuw (20-21).
The first consonant is very hard to read as n, but that is what is must be.

This place is mentioned in CP21v: Aya na səvə prəbu vaṁṅi ṅaran·na Iñana prəbu nis·kala vas·tu kañcana nu surup· di nusa §§ laraṁ “There is a king’s son, his name was fragrant, he is Prebu Niskala Wastu Kancana who has been burried in the Nusa Larang”.
The first consonant is unclear. If we are to follow HD who reads ṅabalay, then this means that at the beginning of line 1, we also need to read ṅa. BM contains word ṅabalay.

restoration proposed by HD. Cf. 172, citation from FCP.6a: ti saṁ hyiṁ talaga vaṙna miñak· hanət· sagomboṁ Uyaḥ salave kəlek· lilitan· salave tək·tək· boEḥ putiḥ sakayuḥ hayam· sakurən· “From Talaga Warna: essential oil one gombong, salt 25 kəlek, waist cloth 25 təktək, white cloth one kayuh, chicken one kurən”.

div.p: Om pun. This is the decree/message of his majesty the king of old, inaugurated here with the name Prabu Guru Dewata, (and also) inaugurated here with the name Sri Baduga Maharaja, king of kings in Pakwan Pajajaran, Sri Sang Ratu Dewata, is inaugurated here.

He is the one who demarcates the Pakwan here, (being) the child of Rahyang Dewa Niskala, he one who was released at Gunung Tiga; grandchild of Rahyang Niskala Wastu Kancana, the one who was released to Nusa Larang.
He, that one, produced the decree in the shape of a mountain, made hard the ground with stones; he produced fire-wood; he produced the holy Color Lake.
Victorious, was he! In the year: the five Pandawas carry the earth (i.e. in 1255 Śaka).
First of all this inscription is read by Friederich (442-468).

Then Holle made a series of articles specifically devoted to this inscription (483-488, 90-98, 187-189, following by Pleyte (155-220, Poerbatjaraka (380-418), and the most recent study by Hasan Djafar 1-13.
Re-edited here by Aditia Gunawan & Arlo Griffiths from the EFEO estampages.
In this edition, only Hasan Djafar readings are compared.
